Title: UK embassy guard gave secrets to Russian general, court told
Line: A security guard at the British embassy in Berlin accused of spying for Russia allegedly passed “secret” information about the government to a Russian military attache, a court heard.

Title: UK embassy guard gave secrets to Russian general, court told
Line: David Smith, 57, denied nine offences under the Official Secrets Act when he appeared at Westminster magistrates court on Thursday.

Title: UK embassy guard gave secrets to Russian general, court told
Line: The Briton, who was living in Potsdam in the German capital, is accused of gathering information from the embassy and passing it to someone he believed was a representative of the Russian state, as well as other alleged offences, between October 2020 and August last year.

Title: UK embassy guard gave secrets to Russian general, court told
Line: During his appearance Smith spoke only to give his full name, age and address, and to submit his plea of not guilty.

Title: UK embassy guard gave secrets to Russian general, court told
Line: The court heard the charges included the allegation that Smith tried to communicate by letter with Gen Maj Sergey Chukhurov, a Russian military person based in the Russian embassy in Berlin.

Title: UK embassy guard gave secrets to Russian general, court told
Line: The court was told the material in the letter allegedly contained “details about the activities, identities, addresses and telephone numbers of various members of Her Majesty’s civil service”, in breach of the Official Secrets Act.

Title: UK embassy guard gave secrets to Russian general, court told
Line: Regarding the other eight charges, Smith is accused of committing acts “prejudicial” to the safety and interest of the state by gathering information classified as “secret” about the “activities of Her Majesty’s government” and that he “collected material relating to the operation and layout of the British embassy in Berlin, and that information was calculated to be or might be or was intended to be directly or be indirectly useful to an enemy, namely the Russian state”.

Title: UK embassy guard gave secrets to Russian general, court told
Line: He is also alleged to have made unauthorised photocopies of documents, video recordings of the embassy’s CCTV system and kept sim card packaging he had been asked to dispose of.

Title: UK embassy guard gave secrets to Russian general, court told
Line: Smith also allegedly communicated information about building repairs at the embassy after being “approached by a person you believed to be a member of Russian military intelligence (the GRU)”.

Title: UK embassy guard gave secrets to Russian general, court told
Line: All charges carry a maximum sentence of 14 years.

Title: UK embassy guard gave secrets to Russian general, court told
Line: Smith was denied bail and remanded in custody.

Title: UK embassy guard gave secrets to Russian general, court told
Line: He was extradited to the UK from Germany on Wednesday after his arrest by German police on 10 August 2021.

Title: UK embassy guard gave secrets to Russian general, court told
Line: Scotland Yard said the investigation was led by counter-terrorism officers.

Title: UK embassy guard gave secrets to Russian general, court told
Line: Nick Price, the head of the special crime and counter-terrorism division at the Crown Prosecution Service, said: “David Smith has been charged with nine offences contrary to the Official Secrets Act.

Title: UK embassy guard gave secrets to Russian general, court told
Line: “He is accused of seven offences of collecting information with the intent of sending it to the Russian authorities, one of attempting communication, and one of providing information to a person he believed was a member of the Russian authorities.

Title: UK embassy guard gave secrets to Russian general, court told
Line: “After reviewing the case and authorising charges, we obtained an extradition warrant and worked closely with our German counterparts in order to bring Mr Smith back to the UK.”

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: What is non-domicile status?

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: A person who is registered as non-domiciled with HM Revenue and Customs is tax resident in the UK but does not have to pay UK tax on income and capital gains earned overseas – including on company stocks or cash made from selling a second home – unless they bring their money into the UK or deposit it into a UK bank account.

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: However, non-doms do still have to pay tax on money earned within the UK.

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: Who qualifies as a non-dom resident?

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: A person with non-dom status is someone who lives in the UK and is tax resident here, but who has their permanent home outside the country.

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: They must demonstrate to HMRC that their domicile – at least for tax purposes – is in another country.

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: Usually their domicile will be the country that their father considered their permanent home when they were born, and to which they intend to eventually return, perhaps when they retire.

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: Because they are tax resident in the UK, non-doms will typically not be tax resident in their country of domicile, and therefore not liable for tax in either country on their worldwide income.

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: Non-doms have to specifically apply for a tax exemption on foreign income of more than £2,000, meaning it is not an automatic designation for foreign-born residents or non-citizens.

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: How long does the non-dom tax break last?

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: After a certain amount of time, non-doms must pay a hefty charge in order to continue sheltering their foreign income from UK tax.

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: Those who have been living in the UK for at least seven of the previous nine tax years must pay £30,000 a year to the government.

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: Those who have lived in the UK for 12 of the previous 14 tax years must pay £60,000 a year.

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: UK residents must pay tax on their worldwide earnings once they have been in the country for 15 of the previous 20 years.

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: Foreign nationals who are resident in the UK can choose to pay British taxes at any point on their worldwide income and capital gains.

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: They do not have to hold a UK passport to be taxed here.

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: Why is it controversial?

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: The rule primarily benefits the very rich, and has allowed those claiming it to avoid paying significant sums to HMRC.

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: A study by the London School of Economics and the University of Warwick found that more than two-fifths of people who earned £5m or more in 2018 had claimed non-dom status at some point since 1997.

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: Some of the highest earning non-doms work in the film industry and sport, including famous actors, directors, producers and Premier League football players, according to the report, which also found that 22% of top-earning bankers have benefited from the scheme.

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: Which big names have claimed UK non-dom status?

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: Some of the most well-known people who have reportedly claimed non-dom status include Roman Abramovich, the Russian oligarch and owner of Chelsea football club now under sanctions, the steel tycoon Lakshmi Mittal and the media baron and Daily Mail owner, Lord Rothermere.

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: Lord Ashcroft, the multimillionaire and former deputy chairman of the Conservative party, and the former HSBC boss Stuart Gulliver were also reported to have used the non-dom scheme.

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: The same applied to Sir James Goldsmith and his children, including the Conservative minister and longtime friend of Boris Johnson, Zac Goldsmith.

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: What about the chancellor’s wife?

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: It emerged on Wednesday that Rishi Sunak’s wife, Akshata Murty, claims non-dom status, allowing her to potentially save millions of pounds in tax on dividends collected from her family’s IT business empire.

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: Murty’s father is the billionaire founder of the Indian-headquartered company Infosys, in which she holds a 0.9% stake.

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?
Line: Her non-dom status means she is not liable to pay the 39.35% tax applied to dividend payouts for UK-resident taxpayers in the highest income band.

Title: What is non-domicile status and who qualifies?

Title: Wet Leg: Wet Leg review – going beyond the chaise longue on nuanced debut
Line: The novelty song is a dying art form.

Title: Wet Leg: Wet Leg review – going beyond the chaise longue on nuanced debut
Line: Deliberately silly, often profoundly annoying earworms by unestablished artists rarely factor into today’s pop universe.

Title: Wet Leg: Wet Leg review – going beyond the chaise longue on nuanced debut
Line: Instead, they have been replaced by the viral hit: a song by a nascent star that swiftly rises from obscurity to ubiquity, sating the appetite for newness and surprise with a bit more coolness and class.

Title: Wet Leg: Wet Leg review – going beyond the chaise longue on nuanced debut
Line: Although the viral hit is implicitly attention-grabbing, it doesn’t tend to be gimmicky – usually the accompanying social media craze (TikTok dance, or back in the day, Twitter meme template) takes care of that.

Title: Wet Leg: Wet Leg review – going beyond the chaise longue on nuanced debut
Line: Occasionally, there comes a viral hit that dances on the edge of novelty territory – comedic, a bit weird and infuriatingly catchy – but, crucially, not without serious musical panache.

Title: Wet Leg: Wet Leg review – going beyond the chaise longue on nuanced debut
Line: In 2019, that song was Old Town Road, the country-trap smash by Nicki Minaj stan turned musician Lil Nas X.

Title: Wet Leg: Wet Leg review – going beyond the chaise longue on nuanced debut
Line: Last year, it was minimalist indie number Chaise Longue by Isle of Wight duo Wet Leg, AKA late twentysomethings Rhian Teasdale and Hester Chambers.

Title: Wet Leg: Wet Leg review – going beyond the chaise longue on nuanced debut
Line: Over a monotonous bass line and sirening post-punk riff, a deadpan Teasdale intoned a series of non sequiturs – from suggestive Mean Girls quotes (“would you like us to assign someone to butter your muffin?”) to suggestive allusions to academia (“I went to school and I got the big D”).

Title: Wet Leg: Wet Leg review – going beyond the chaise longue on nuanced debut
Line: The chorus – essentially, “on the Chaise Longue” repeated ad infinitum in staccato style – combined with the vaguely gross-out band name sealed its strange, adolescent appeal.

Title: Wet Leg: Wet Leg review – going beyond the chaise longue on nuanced debut
Line: At 13m Spotify streams, the numbers aren’t exactly at Drivers License levels (that particular viral hit is on more than 1.3bn streams), but the hype Chaise Longue has generated on both sides of the Atlantic is far from negligible – they came second in the BBC’s influential Sound of 2022 poll and have appeared on several late-night US chatshows.

Title: Wet Leg: Wet Leg review – going beyond the chaise longue on nuanced debut
Line: Yet there is a price to pay for such teasing flamboyance.

Title: Wet Leg: Wet Leg review – going beyond the chaise longue on nuanced debut
Line: Firstly, you risk being seen as an irritant – I can’t be the only one who found Chaise Longue’s irreverence rather ersatz, and its supposedly witty innuendoes more like sub-Carry On inanity.

Title: Wet Leg: Wet Leg review – going beyond the chaise longue on nuanced debut
Line: Secondly, you introduce a certain amount of scepticism towards your first proper body of work.

Title: Wet Leg: Wet Leg review – going beyond the chaise longue on nuanced debut
Line: Are Wet Leg just a flash in the pan?

Title: Wet Leg: Wet Leg review – going beyond the chaise longue on nuanced debut
Line: While their eponymous debut album will no doubt disappoint fans of endless double entendres, it may just convert the cynics.

Title: Wet Leg: Wet Leg review – going beyond the chaise longue on nuanced debut
Line: Much like Lil Nas X did with his debut, the pair don’t repeat the style of their brash breakthrough hit, but have instead produced a far more subtle and conventional record.

Title: Wet Leg: Wet Leg review – going beyond the chaise longue on nuanced debut
Line: Wet Leg – mostly recorded in cocoon-like circumstances before Chaise Longue’s release, with help from producer du jour Dan Carey (Black Midi, Fontaines DC) – is a collection of 90s and 00s-era indie that is by turns dreamy, lush, hooky and thunderous, and layered with lyrics saturated with millennial disaffection, anxiety and overwhelm.

Title: Wet Leg: Wet Leg review – going beyond the chaise longue on nuanced debut
Line: The tracks that bookend the album are among the best examples of this approach: opener Being in Love – in which a satisfyingly original twist on the idea of infatuation as mental instability is relayed through the medium of scuzzy/delicate rock – and closer Too Late Now, a stormy tribute to opportunities passing you by and alienation setting in.

Title: Wet Leg: Wet Leg review – going beyond the chaise longue on nuanced debut
Line: The latter has a gratifyingly relatable self-doubt break, when the music drops out to allow Teasdale to document her existential angst as it spreads into the track she is currently performing: “I’m not sure if this is a song / I don’t even know what I’m saying … I’m not sure if this is the kind of life that I saw myself living.” The quarter-life crisis – rendered in messy, anxiety-riven, circular thought patterns – is perhaps the unifying motif of Wet Leg.

Title: Wet Leg: Wet Leg review – going beyond the chaise longue on nuanced debut
Line: On the psychedelic I Don’t Wanna Go Out, whose recurring riff nods to Bowie’s The Man Who Sold the World, our narrator is “almost 28, still getting off my stupid face.” On Angelica, sourly chiming guitars soundtrack a woman miserably going through the motions at a party; Oh No reflects on the infinite scroll while only just managing to suppress screeching panic.

Title: Wet Leg: Wet Leg review – going beyond the chaise longue on nuanced debut
Line: There are more in-yer-face tracks – with its hummed bass line and ambling raucousness, Supermarket’s tale of being stoned while doing the big shop recalls first-wave British punk in spirit and subject matter, while Wet Dream archly rejects the idea of being the object of masturbatory fantasies – but there is a maudlin air to these, too.

Title: Wet Leg: Wet Leg review – going beyond the chaise longue on nuanced debut
Line: The music is more muted and bittersweet than on Chaise Longue, as are the jokes – which actually make sense this time.

Title: Wet Leg: Wet Leg review – going beyond the chaise longue on nuanced debut
Line: That Teasdale and Chambers are able to treat great lines like throwaway remarks – as on the sweetly incantatory Loving You, which features the jibe: “I hope you choke on your girlfriend” – is proof they have wit to spare.

Title: Wet Leg: Wet Leg review – going beyond the chaise longue on nuanced debut
Line: You have to concede that in the content-saturated streaming age, arriving with a bit of goonish novelty probably isn’t a bad way to kickstart a career.

Title: Wet Leg: Wet Leg review – going beyond the chaise longue on nuanced debut
Line: Wet Leg have certainly got people listening, and by channelling their sense of humour and showmanship into a series of tracks that are far more nuanced and three-dimensional than the infuriatingly repetitive song that made their name, they’ve ensured their debut album is well worth hearing – again and again and again.

Title: Meta plans ‘Zuck bucks’ virtual coins for Facebook and Instagram users
Line: Mark Zuckerberg is looking to develop virtual coins, nicknamed “Zuck bucks” by staff, for users of Facebook and Instagram as part of a suite of products designed to reduce his platforms’ dependence on advertising in the future metaverse.

Title: Meta plans ‘Zuck bucks’ virtual coins for Facebook and Instagram users
Line: Facebook’s parent group, Meta, is looking to develop a range of virtual products – including digital tokens and “creator coins” – to diversify income and revitalise its user base, which is increasingly turning to newer rivals such as TikTok.

Title: Meta plans ‘Zuck bucks’ virtual coins for Facebook and Instagram users
Line: While Meta remains the dominant social media network provider – its revenues rose 37% to $118bn in 2021 as advertisers clamoured to reach the 4.9 billion monthly active users of Facebook and Instagram – TikTok has also built up a massive non-ads business based on in-app purchases and e-commerce.

Title: Meta plans ‘Zuck bucks’ virtual coins for Facebook and Instagram users
Line: Meta, which has proven quick to ape successful products rolled out by rivals such as Snapchat, is now exploring ways to further monetise its user base, according to the Financial Times, which first reported the story.

Title: Meta plans ‘Zuck bucks’ virtual coins for Facebook and Instagram users
Line: Products being looked at include “social tokens” or “reputation tokens”, which could be used as rewards by users.

Title: Meta plans ‘Zuck bucks’ virtual coins for Facebook and Instagram users
Line: It is also looking at “creator coins”, which could be used by influencers on Instagram.

Title: Meta plans ‘Zuck bucks’ virtual coins for Facebook and Instagram users
Line: Like Amazon’s Twitch, TikTok uses a tipping system whereby fans can buy its coins to then buy gifts to give to their favourite creators.

Title: Meta plans ‘Zuck bucks’ virtual coins for Facebook and Instagram users
Line: Creators can also buy coins to use tools such as Promote to boost a TikTok video’s profile, increasing viewers or followers.

Title: Meta plans ‘Zuck bucks’ virtual coins for Facebook and Instagram users
Line: The initiatives, led by Facebook’s financial arm, Meta Financial Technologies, follow the company’s ill-fated foray into attempting to create a global cryptocurrency, a project called Libra and later Diem, which was abandoned earlier this year after issues with US regulators.

Title: Meta plans ‘Zuck bucks’ virtual coins for Facebook and Instagram users
Line: That was not the first time Facebook had looked to move into the world of virtual finance.

Title: Meta plans ‘Zuck bucks’ virtual coins for Facebook and Instagram users
Line: In 2009 it launched Facebook Credits to facilitate in-app purchases in then highly popular games such as Zynga’s FarmVille.

Title: Meta plans ‘Zuck bucks’ virtual coins for Facebook and Instagram users
Line: While successful, it was shut four years later after Facebook’s international growth made for costly foreign currency conversions.

Title: Meta plans ‘Zuck bucks’ virtual coins for Facebook and Instagram users
Line: Meta is also looking to enter the world of non-fungible tokens (NFTs), with plans to allow their integration into Instagram and Facebook.

Title: California woman wins $10m after accidentally buying wrong lottery ticket
Line: A woman accidentally bought the wrong lottery ticket after an unknown stranger bumped into her as she made a purchase from an automatic machine – only to discover she had hit the jackpot and scooped a whopping $10m prize.

Title: California woman wins $10m after accidentally buying wrong lottery ticket
Line: California TV station KABC reported that LaQuedra Edwards was at a Vons supermarket in the city of Tarzana when she put $40 into a vending machine.

Title: California woman wins $10m after accidentally buying wrong lottery ticket
Line: She described how “some rude person” bumped into her as she was selecting her options and she ended up mistakenly purchasing a $30 ticket.

Title: California woman wins $10m after accidentally buying wrong lottery ticket
Line: “He just bumped into me, didn’t say a thing and just walked out the door,” Edwards said in a statement released by the California Lottery.

Title: California woman wins $10m after accidentally buying wrong lottery ticket
Line: She then returned to her car, scratched off the ticket and discovered she had won a gigantic sum of money.

Title: California woman wins $10m after accidentally buying wrong lottery ticket
Line: “I didn’t really believe it at first, but I got on the 405 Freeway and kept looking down at [the ticket] and I almost crashed my car,” Edwards said.

Title: California woman wins $10m after accidentally buying wrong lottery ticket
Line: According to the statement, Edwards plans on buying a house and setting up a charity organization.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: Ever since Sunset Boulevard’s dead protagonist floated into view in the iconic opening sequence of Billy Wilder’s 1950 film, a drama set in a Los Angeles suburb with a swimming pool as its central feature has carried ominous connotations.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: Daddy’s heated pool is set within a contemporary Bel Air mansion, and is modelled on David Hockney’s swimming pool paintings of the 1960s and 70s.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: It colonises most of the stage.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: But the play’s protagonist is very much alive, erupting out of the water in Speedos in the opening scene.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: This is a sign to expect the unexpected in this bold, brawny, flamboyantly theatrical production written by Jeremy O Harris and first staged off Broadway in 2019.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: It features an unequal relationship between Franklin (Terique Jarrett), a young Black American artist, and Andre (Claes Bang) an older, white, billionaire art collector who becomes his lover, and whose nickname, “Daddy”, is taken from a moment of sexual role play.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: Their alliance is queasy from the start, with flecks of Death in Venice but with race, money and art patronage added to the mix; the question of who is exploiting whom hangs indeterminately between them.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: Throw in Franklin’s churchgoing, gospel-singing moralist mother (Sharlene Whyte) and a mischievous choir (Rebecca Bernice Amissah, Keisha Atwell, T’Shan Williams, all three fabulous) that pops up to heighten the mood and we get the melodrama of the play’s subtitle.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: The mood is impish and knowing with cool disco beats, sudden spotlights, and a hammy rendition of George Michael’s Father Figure.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: But for all the theatrics, there is enough sophistication in the writing and in Danya Taymor’s direction for these elements to work to thrilling effect.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: The short first half brings sharp art world satire through Franklin’s gallerist (Jenny Rainsford), who is at pains to market him to wealthy white clients in exactly the right way.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: Franklin’s friends, meanwhile, always featured poolside, bring teen-movie satire: Bellamy (Ioanna Kimbrook) is an Insta addict in skimpy swimwear while Max (John McCrea) is a snarky geek who together make an entertainingly vapid double act.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: There are deadly serious issues at play: Andre regards his lover as he might an objet d’art, to be gazed at and admired.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: There is not only exoticisation (“chocolate” skin is mentioned) but ownership, too (“You are mine”), and Franklin’s body is always on show, barely clad for the duration of the play.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: Andre’s white gaze extends to Franklin’s art work; Jean-Michel Basquiat is mentioned at the start, as well as the question of how the value of artwork changes when it is brought into a gallery.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: Franklin first creates miniature black dolls and then lifesize figures, all of which are sold to rich white celebrity types, as his mother observes.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: Complicated questions arise out of his art-making: how is blackness packaged and sold in America’s contemporary art market?

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: How does this art world view work made by a queer black artist?

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: And is Franklin colluding in this process for his own gain?

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: A sensational first half hooks us into every last intrigue and all the actors work wonders: Bang, as Andre, has a raffish, Rupert Everett look and gives off a buzzing sense of predation.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: Jarrett is exquisite as Franklin, balancing innocence with knowing and trauma with playfulness.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: Whyte’s mother is a baroque creation, both funny and alarming – a preacher in disguise, belting out her moral warnings against her son’s sinful living in song.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: She turns darker in the second half, and every other character feels skewed so that the drama becomes more feverish and surreal.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: This longer second part is less masterful than the first.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: The story seems to dismantle itself but to throw out too many things at once, without following them through deeply.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: Oedipal strains are felt and buried trauma unearthed in Franklin’s memories of his real, abandoning “daddy”.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: The play moves into the territory of psychodrama and becomes opaque, locking us out with unexpected turns rather than carry us with it, as the first half has done.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: But in spite of these frustrations, Daddy never ceases to be interesting.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: And if there was ever a play wholly worth watching for its perfectly formed first half, this is it.

Title: Daddy: A Melodrama review – Black art, white money and love in Speedos
Line: Daddy is at the Almeida theatre, London, until 30 April.

Title: Elmer and Mr Benn author David McKee dies at 87
Line: David McKee, the author and illustrator of the iconic children’s books Elmer, Not Now, Bernard and Mr Benn, has died aged 87, his publisher has said.

Title: Elmer and Mr Benn author David McKee dies at 87
Line: The author and illustrator died surrounded by family in the south of France following a short illness.

Title: Elmer and Mr Benn author David McKee dies at 87
Line: After a lifetime of travelling the world, he and his partner Bakhta, a French-Algerian art dealer, had been dividing their time between London and Provence in recent years.

Title: Elmer and Mr Benn author David McKee dies at 87
Line: His long time publisher Klaus Flugge said he was devastated by the news.

Title: Elmer and Mr Benn author David McKee dies at 87
Line: “His was a singular voice and a shining light in children’s books that highlighted inclusivity, diversity and parts of our world that are not always present in publishing for children.” He added: “Not only was I fortunate to be his publisher, he was also a wonderful friend, and he will be missed by many more people than he could ever imagine.” McKee was born in Tavistock, Devon, and studied at Plymouth Art College.

Title: Elmer and Mr Benn author David McKee dies at 87
Line: His first book Two Can Toucan was published in 1964 by Flugge when he worked at Abelard-Schuman.

Title: Elmer and Mr Benn author David McKee dies at 87
Line: When Flugge founded Andersen Press in 1976, McKee moved with him and went on to create more than 50 books for the publisher.

Title: Elmer and Mr Benn author David McKee dies at 87
Line: McKee wrote and illustrated 29 original stories about the beloved multi-coloured patchwork elephant Elmer, the first of which was published in 1968.

Title: Elmer and Mr Benn author David McKee dies at 87
Line: The books remain one of the most widely read children’s book series of all time: more than 10m copies have been sold, and they have been translated into more than 60 languages.

Title: Elmer and Mr Benn author David McKee dies at 87
Line: The themes of inclusivity, celebration and friendship that run through the Elmer stories led the Guardian to hail Elmer as an LGBT hero in 2014.

Title: Elmer and Mr Benn author David McKee dies at 87
Line: “I never intended to do that,” McKee said in an interview at the time, “but I suspect there are subconscious processes at work I only discover later.” As well as writing and illustrating children’s books, McKee had a successful career as a fine artist, and as a co-creator of animated TV programmes including Mr Benn, based on his series of books about an explorer’s magical adventures.

Title: Elmer and Mr Benn author David McKee dies at 87
Line: The series celebrated its 50th anniversary last year.

Title: Elmer and Mr Benn author David McKee dies at 87
Line: McKee was named the BookTrust Lifetime Achievement award winner in 2020.

Title: Elmer and Mr Benn author David McKee dies at 87
Line: “David McKee understands the importance of always paying attention to children and what he gives them is first-rate,” said chair of judges Nicolette Jones when announcing his win.

Title: Elmer and Mr Benn author David McKee dies at 87
Line: Speaking to the Guardian in 2020, McKee said: “I’ve often said I think the air is full of stories – you just have to have the right receiver and you pick them up.”

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: On Tuesday, Oklahoma became the latest state to pass a bill to make performing an abortion a felony, punishable, in this case, by 10 years in prison and a $100,000 fine.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: The bill is expected to be signed into law by the governor, creating an even larger group of people – about 7.7 million between Texas and Oklahoma – who will have to leave their home state if they want an abortion.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: Republican legislators are passing restrictions and bans on abortion, in expectation of a supreme court decision in a crucial abortion rights case expected in June.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: Until then, abortion remains legal, albeit severely restricted in some cases, across the US.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: There was some hope that medication abortions might help alleviate this pressure.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: In July 2020, the US Food and Drug Administration announced that anyone seeking a medication abortion – that is, an abortion by taking pills, up to 10 weeks into a pregnancy, without the need for an operation – would no longer have to pick up the medication in person, or take it in a doctor’s presence.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: Its decision to stop enforcing in-person requirements for the abortion drug mifepristone was a response to the Covid-19 pandemic, but in December, in consensus with the medical community, it ended the requirement for good.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: Mifepristone, which data shows is safer than acetaminophen, is now available for US patients to acquire via telehealth services like Abortion on Demand and Just The Pill, which offer online appointments and discreet mail order medications.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: Consultations and ordering are straightforward and user-friendly on these sites and pills are posted in less than five days.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: People may take it without a provider’s oversight in the comfort and privacy of their own homes, just as they did after obtaining it in-person from a doctor.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: The FDA’s decision empowered a wave of certified virtual clinics.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: In the coming months, the FDA is expected to clarify how pharmacies, like Walgreens and CVS, can distribute mifepristone for the first time.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: The increased accessibility of abortion medication is a huge asset to people living in states that permit it – in fact, medication abortion accounted for 54% of all US abortions in 2020, up from 39% in 2017, according to research from the pro-choice Guttmacher Institute.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: “We were overjoyed [at the FDA’s decision], because over the years we’ve been building evidence that continues to show that people who want to use [mifepristone] to end their pregnancy … they are very capable of being able to read the instructions and do so on their own,” says Liza Fuentes, a senior research scientist at the Guttmacher Institute.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: However, 19 states currently have laws requiring an in-person element to abortions, such as an ultrasound or an in-person counseling session, precluding a totally virtual experience.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: And some states, including Texas, Arizona, and Louisiana ban abortion telehealth services outright.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: For those seeking an abortion in states where it is restricted, acquiring abortion pills through the mail is a much quicker and more affordable option than having to travel across state lines for an in-person appointment.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: Already, says Rachel Rebouché, interim dean of Temple University’s law school, people seeking medication abortions can use social media to find advice on how to change their VPNs, have pills illicitly mailed to a FedEx drop-off point in a neighboring state, or how to have pills sent to someone else who can deliver them.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: But Republicans are aggressively restricting access to telehealth care for abortions in red states, with many creating trigger laws aimed at banning or severely restricting abortion across the board should Roe v Wade be overturned.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: And while some states have interstate agreements allowing healthcare providers to offer telehealth services across borders, providers are beholden to the laws of the patient’s home state, preventing blue state doctors from mailing abortion medication to red state patients.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: Republicans are also attempting to amend anti-abortion bills further to prevent red state residents from getting abortions regardless of where the abortion takes place – even if they travel to a blue state to access in-person or telehealth care.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: Even if, for instance, a resident of an anti-abortion state traveled to California, these laws would see that their body remained under the jurisdiction of their home state.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: Some red states could likely already prosecute under existing accomplice and conspiracy laws.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: “You see states like Missouri trying to attach its laws to providers who are providing abortions outside of Missouri, but trying to think about how to civilly penalize those providers by saying ‘any provider who provides an abortion to a Missouri resident is bound by the laws of Missouri,’” says Rebouché.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: Experts anticipate the brunt of aggressive anti-abortion enforcement will be disproportionately borne by those with few resources – people of color, low-income families, and the young.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: Blue states are working to enshrine abortion rights within and beyond their borders, with some refusing to accept that state legislatures can impinge on the sovereignty of other states by enforcing laws beyond their own jurisdictions.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: California and Connecticut are both actively advancing abortion rights, working to shield “providers from legal liability and prevent them from being extradited” and by creating networks for travel for abortion and centers for abortion care, says Rebouché.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: “The inevitable reality is that even though there is legal liability at stake, mailing abortion medication and administering those pills at home can be really hard to detect,” she adds.

Title: Mail-order abortion pills become next US reproductive rights battleground
Line: “Some states will try to enforce [abortion bans] but others will not because it won’t be worth the cost and it’s going to be difficult to do.”

Title: Grand National 2022: horse-by-horse guide to all the runners

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: Just months after Akshata Murty was born in April 1980, she was sent to live with her paternal grandparents after her parents moved hundreds of miles away to Mumbai for work.

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: “Your mother and I were young then and struggling to find our feet in our careers,” her father wrote in a letter to Akshata, which was published in Legacy; Letters from eminent parents to their daughter.

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: “Two months after your birth in Hubli [a city near Goa], we brought you to Mumbai, but discovered quickly enough that it was a difficult task to nurture a child and manage careers side by side.

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: So, we decided that you would spend the initial years of your life with your grandparents in Hubli.” Her father, NR Narayana Murthy, a young computer programmer who would go on to launch the IT services company Infosys and become a billionaire, said leaving Akshata behind was one of the hardest decisions he had had to make.

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: “Every weekend, I would take the plane to Belgaum [a nearby airport] and then hire a car to Hubli.

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: It was very expensive, but I couldn’t do without seeing you.” Her mother, Sudha Murty, a computer scientist and engineer, was the first female engineer to work for India’s then largest carmaker, part of the Tata conglomerate, and is now a philanthropist working to improve public healthcare.

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: When Akshata did join her parents, and later her brother, Rohan, in Mumbai, life might not have been as relaxed as it was with her grandparents in Hubli.

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: Sudha “decided early on that there would be no TV in our home so that there would be time for things like studying, reading, discussions and meeting friends”, according to the book.

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: Every evening, 8pm to 10pm was dedicated to “pursuits that brought the family together in a productive environment”.

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: For Akshata and Rohan, that meant homework, while their parents “read books on history, literature, physics, mathematics and engineering, or did any office work”.

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: As the family became increasingly rich, Akshata’s parents eschewed hiring a private car and driver to take her school, preferring to stick with the “regular autorickshaw” where she made “great friends with the ‘rickshaw uncle’”.

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: Murty went to the private liberal Claremont McKenna College in California, where she studied economics and French, before moving to the Fashion Institute of Design and Merchandising in Los Angeles.

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: She worked for Deloitte and Unilever before studying for an MBA at Stanford University.

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: It was at Stanford that she met Rishi Sunak, who had won a prestigious Fulbright scholarship.

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: Within four years, they were married in a two-day ceremony in Bengaluru, attended by cricketing royalty including the Indian spinner Anil Kumble and the family of Rahul Dravid, the former captain of the national cricket team.

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: Her father said he was a “little sad and jealous” when Akshata first told him of her new life partner.

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: “But when I met Rishi and found him to be all that you had described him to be – brilliant, handsome and, most importantly, honest – I understood why you let your heart be stolen.” After Stanford, she joined a Dutch clean technology incubator fund in San Francisco as marketing director in 2007, but left quickly to start her own fashion label, Akshata Designs.

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: “I understand that there may be some curiosity around what I’m doing given my parents’ achievements, but I hope that one day this business is able to stand on its own feet and I’m able to speak on its merit rather than anything else,” she told the Times of India in 2009 when she founded the business.

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: “This is my passion and I couldn’t imagine being engaged in anything else but the business of this venture.” The business, however, collapsed within three years.

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: Money comes in from her 0.91% stake in Infosys, which is valued at about $900m (£690m), making Murty richer than the Queen (£365m).

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: The couple also own London-based Catamaran Ventures UK, which invests in startups “with the view to future capital growth and income distributions”.

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: Sunak transferred his shares to her just before entering parliament, and she is now the sole owner.

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: She has direct shareholdings in at least six other UK companies, including the gentlemen’s outfitters New & Lingwood, which measures Etonians for their tailcoats and sells silk dressing gowns for £2,500 each.

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: Murty also holds shares in a UK business that operates Jamie Oliver’s Pizzeria, Jamie’s Italian and Wendy’s outlets in India, the nanny agency Koru Kids, and the gym operator Digme Fitness, where she is a director.

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: Both New & Lingwood and Digme furloughed staff during the pandemic.

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: Murty and Sunak own at least four homes in the UK and California, including a five-bedroom mews house in Kensington valued at almost £7m, and a £1.5m Georgian mansion set in 12 acres in Sunak’s North Yorkshire constituency, as well as a flat on the Old Brompton Road in west London.

Title: Akshata Murty: Rishi Sunak’s wife and richer than the Queen
Line: They also own a Santa Monica beach penthouse valued at £5.5m, which the property developer describes as having “stunning views of the Santa Monica mountains” and where you “wake up to the sound of waves crashing against the shore”.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Commuters to London’s Liverpool Street were treated to a taboo-busting billboard last week, featuring a mother of two weightlifting, while leaking actual liquid.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: The ad is part of the “leaks happen” campaign, from the women’s health brand Elvie, aiming to raise awareness of a common, but largely obscured, problem – postpartum incontinence.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Claire Hackett, the Alliance party rep for Mid Ulster in Northern Ireland, can testify first-hand how women are suffering in silence, and says that openness is exactly what’s needed.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: When she returned to work 10 months after the birth of her third child, the impact of injuries following all three births continued to complicate her life.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: “I can remember the sweat and the fear of ‘Oh my God, what might happen if I don’t get to the toilet’.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: It’s things like this that you don’t really want to talk to people about.” Hackett’s difficulties started about 10 years ago, after having her first child, which left her with a third-degree tear – meaning the rupture went as far as the muscle that controls the anus.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: After surgery, Hackett was handed a leaflet for pelvic floor exercises.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Eight months later, she still hadn’t healed, and was experiencing stinging while urinating as well as bladder control problems.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: “My husband and I hadn’t had sex at that point because I was still so scared of what was going on with my pelvic region,” she says.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: She was referred to a “back class”, where women got together and did a circuit of back exercises, which helped strengthen her core, but achieved little else.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Many women, says Hackett, are too afraid, ashamed or embarrassed to draw attention to their pelvic problems after childbirth.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Added to this is the coy acceptance of the problem, “like in Tena ads for your little ‘oops’ moments.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Like this is just what happens to women,” she says.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: “Yes, it’s common to experience incontinence.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: But it’s not normal: there are things that can be done.” Myra Robson, a clinical lead physiotherapist and co-founder of the pelvic health campaign group Pelvicroar, says part of the problem is that women aren’t adequately prepared for birth trauma.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: “There’s still a much greater emphasis on this lovely romantic version of childbirth.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: People aren’t prepared for the fact that there can be a problem when you’re trying to get a whole human being out of this relatively small space,” she says.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: “I think we’re very unrealistic about that.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: We need to empower women to vocalise when they’re having problems and do something about it.” It’s certainly not a niche concern: as many as one in three women experience urinary incontinence in the three months after childbirth, according to the National Childbirth Trust (NCT).

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: And it can also develop in the years that follow.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: According to Julie Cornish, colorectal consultant at the Cardiff and Vale University Health Board and vice-president of the MASIC Foundation – a charity that supports women who have been severely injured during childbirth – research shows that one in five women develop problems controlling their bowels in the first five years after giving birth vaginally.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Being pregnant and giving birth can also weaken the pelvic floor – the supportive hammock made of muscles and tissues that keeps the pelvic organs (the uterus, bladder and bowel) in place.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: When the pelvic floor is overstretched – if the baby is large, during an assisted birth (using forceps, for example) or if labour is prolonged – one or more of these organs can descend (prolapse) into the vagina.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: One writer described the experience as a feeling of constantly sitting on an egg.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: But women are not necessarily warned of these risks, says Ranee Thakar, vice-president of the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: “Mothers tell me – when I see them – that nobody ever told them that these [pelvic floor disorders] could happen.” After childbirth there is a lot of focus on the baby – and rightly so, says Thakar.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: “But we also need to think about the mother, especially given pelvic problems are not always readily apparent after delivery.” Undetected or mild birth trauma can escalate into more serious conditions as women age, she adds.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Postnatal care has long been patchy – even before the pandemic – partly due to a lack of education among healthcare professionals as well as the embarrassment and stigma that impedes mothers from reporting their issues in the first place.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Covid simply exacerbated these underlying fissures, says Cornish: “We are facing a massive uphill battle, because cancer cases are going to be taking priority and so pelvic floor problems get pushed to the back of the queue again.” For the most part, pregnant women are offered some education by the NHS about what to expect all the way through to delivery, but these classes are not uniform across the country.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: After birth, women are typically given a leaflet with instructions for exercises they can do to get their pelvic floor muscles back into shape (although pinpointing those muscles can be tricky).

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Meanwhile, postnatal care is largely the responsibility of community midwives.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Around the six- to eight-week mark, a postnatal check on mother and baby is conducted by GPs. If a serious injury emerges, mothers are typically referred to secondary care.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Twenty years ago, there were three or four clinics focused on pelvic floor problems across the UK, but while there are many more now, says Thakar, “they’re not there everywhere”.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Waiting lists are long and increasing staff shortages haven’t helped.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: “In terms of a full pelvic floor assessment,” says Robson, “it’s usually the physiotherapists that do it, and there’s just simply not enough of us to go around.” Christine Sweet, who lives in Greater Manchester, gave birth for the first time in June 2021.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Her delivery involved an episiotomy (an incision between the vaginal opening and the anus to make more space for the baby), as well as forceps, both well-known risk factors for future pelvic complications.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: She was discharged from hospital about 24 hours after giving birth and put in the care of a community midwifery team.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: A few days later, her episiotomy stitches came apart.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: In pain, Sweet went to her GP, who diagnosed her with an infection, suggesting it was acquired in hospital.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: The doctor was “horrified at the sight of the wound and didn’t know what to do.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: She rang gynaecology at the hospital, and they said that until the infection had been cleared, they weren’t prepared to see me.” Sweet says that having an open wound that wasn’t healing was more painful than the labour.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: “Nobody seemed to know what to do with it, or what should be done to keep the wound clean and who was meant to be reviewing it.” Eventually, after four courses of antibiotics, the infection cleared, but Sweet was told her problem did not satisfy the criteria for urgent referral to gynaecology.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: The waiting list for a standard appointment was hovering between six months and a year.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Twelve weeks after the birth of her son, she managed to find some childcare, and went to A&E.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: After hours of waiting, it was determined her wound needed to be cauterised – a process in which electricity or chemicals are used to burn tissue in order to close a wound.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: It was done there and then, and healed soon after, but that wasn’t end of her problems.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Finally, more than three months after giving birth, she had a full internal examination with a pelvic health physio team, where it was confirmed that she had developed a prolapse.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: “It seems that if you have a baby, you should expect to be in pain,” said Sweet.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: “But the more you try to keep a lid on it … it doesn’t give women the true picture of what can go wrong, and then importantly how you can fix things once they have gone wrong.” Melissa Bubnic, a freelance script writer in London, has been on a waiting list for reparative surgery for more than a year.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Bubnic initially realised something was wrong in 2019, three months after giving birth to her second child.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Sitting on the bus on her way to an event, she smelled something odd.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: A visit to the loo confirmed her fears – she had soiled herself.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Fortunately, she had wet wipes on hand, but about a month later, it happened again.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: When she saw her GP that May, she was referred to pelvic specialists at a London hospital.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: With demand far outstripping supply for such services, it could take up to a year to get an appointment.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Finally, in November 2019, she went for an endoanal scan.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: “I wanted to believe that everything was OK,” says Bubnic, “so I asked if everything was OK back there.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: She said, ‘No, it’s really not OK.’” “It was the first time anyone had told me that something was really wrong – I had had a fourth-degree tear that had been missed.” It was likely, she was told, that the tear had occurred back in 2015, during the birth of her first child, when she was given an episiotomy and forceps had been used.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: By May 2020, she still hadn’t been able to see an NHS physiotherapist – and felt as if she was being dissuaded from seeking the opinion of a colorectal surgeon.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: “I was told that a referral would be made but whenever I called, they couldn’t find the referral in the system.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: And I had to kind of get a bit cross.” She finally saw a colorectal surgeon in November 2020 and was put on the waiting list for surgery, but the pandemic has increased delays.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Tired of waiting, she took a punt on an advertisement posted by a PhD student investigating the impact of serious birth trauma.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: She was assessed by a medical team at St Mark’s hospital, a specialist bowel hospital in Harrow, London, earlier this year, and underwent surgery there last month.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: “I have been so incredibly lucky,” she said.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Both Bubnic and Hackett have sought out private physiotherapy, too.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: “I just always thought, you have babies, you wet yourself,” says Hackett.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: “It’s just what you have to put up with.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: So, to find out that I could rehab my pelvic floor to the level that I have, and it’s still not even perfect … I couldn’t believe it.” The cost for private physiotherapy can be prohibitive at about £100 for the initial consultation (depending on geography), and slightly lower rates for follow-up appointments.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Many campaigners cite France as a country with better pelvic healthcare.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Mothers there are automatically prescribed multiple sessions of physio to “re-educate” their pelvic floor after delivery.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: But there is acknowledgment that postpartum care in the UK is ripe for improvement, and earlier this year NHS England announced the opening of 14 new pelvic health clinics, bringing together midwives, specialist doctors and physiotherapists to improve the prevention, identification and treatment of pelvic floor dysfunction.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Physical injuries aside, the sexual and mental health impact of postpartum trauma is devastating, says Bubnic.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: “You just feel so sexless and dirty.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Incontinence is so mortifying.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: The mental health impact of being scared to leave your house, or having an accident – every women who has these injuries has to deal with that.” When Bubnic first discovered the severity of her injury, she didn’t know anybody else who had faced a similar situation.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: “I felt so ashamed and embarrassed,” she says.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: “I need a lot of support around managing the injury and navigating this labyrinthine health system.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: Even when you want to talk to NHS staff, who are trying to help you, bringing up the sex aspect, everyone looks a bit awkward and doesn’t really know what to say.

Title: ‘You feel so sexless and dirty’: the women living with incontinence after childbirth
Line: “I just don’t believe that if the genders were reversed,” she adds, “if it was men, in the act of becoming fathers, who were ripped from testicles to anus and left incontinent – that we wouldn’t be doing something to address that.”

Title: Project Dictator review – meta clowning lays bare real terror
Line: We begin with a political sketch show that sputteringly descends into farce.

Title: Project Dictator review – meta clowning lays bare real terror
Line: Elements of absurdist theatre seep in, then clowning and finally brooding despair.

Title: Project Dictator review – meta clowning lays bare real terror
Line: Rhum + Clay’s latest devised work is a Russian doll of a production, which peels back the layers of performance until it hollows out completely.

Title: Project Dictator review – meta clowning lays bare real terror
Line: The writers are occasionally a little too entranced by their own ingenuity but there are still plenty of powerful images and ideas here – particularly the growing sense that the time for play and pretence, in such politically fraught times, is over.

Title: Project Dictator review – meta clowning lays bare real terror
Line: Co-directors and performers Matt Wells and Julian Spooner, along with co-director Hamish Macdougall, have conceived Project Dictator in collaboration with a group of international artists, all living under oppressive regimes.

Title: Project Dictator review – meta clowning lays bare real terror
Line: Their influence isn’t felt in direct quotations (the script is far too meta for that) but is instead threaded into the outer edges of the production.

Title: Project Dictator review – meta clowning lays bare real terror
Line: It’s there in the flickers of fear in Wells and Spooner’s eyes as they peek anxiously into the wings; the sinister sway of the music and lighting; the absolute impossibility of stopping the show and beginning again.

Title: Project Dictator review – meta clowning lays bare real terror
Line: Long-term collaborators Wells and Spooner bring out the best in each other.

Title: Project Dictator review – meta clowning lays bare real terror
Line: Wells is the straight guy: a “polymath theatre maker” determined to make his “state of the nation” political satire.

Title: Project Dictator review – meta clowning lays bare real terror
Line: Spooner plays the comedy sidekick, puffing and panting with manic energy and hell bent on creating something fun.

Title: Project Dictator review – meta clowning lays bare real terror
Line: But while they’re a great double act, the earlier scenes feel caught somewhere between an Edinburgh sketch show and high-concept satire.

Title: Project Dictator review – meta clowning lays bare real terror
Line: They never quite take off.

Title: Project Dictator review – meta clowning lays bare real terror
Line: It’s only in the second half, when a diaphanous curtain drops down in front of the stage, that this show finally reveals itself.

Title: Project Dictator review – meta clowning lays bare real terror
Line: We’re left to peer at two clowns, frantically preparing backstage.

Title: Project Dictator review – meta clowning lays bare real terror
Line: It’s a powerful design from Blythe Brett that hints at a darker underbelly we choose to ignore: the fearful reality that lurks beneath all that political clowning.

Title: Project Dictator review – meta clowning lays bare real terror
Line: The music, performed live by Syrian Jazz musician Khaled Kurbeh, suddenly becomes stranger, scarier, ensnaring.

Title: Project Dictator review – meta clowning lays bare real terror
Line: We watch the clowns apply their makeup and, as the white powder swiftly covers over their features, disappear almost completely.

Title: Project Dictator review – meta clowning lays bare real terror
Line: Project Dictator is at New Diorama theatre, London, until 30 April.

Title: Compartment No 6 review – meet-uncute train romance is a Finnish Before Sunrise
Line: Despite the bone-chilling cold of its location in Murmansk in Russia’s remote north-west, there’s a wonderful human warmth and humour in this offbeat romantic story of strangers on a train.

Title: Compartment No 6 review – meet-uncute train romance is a Finnish Before Sunrise
Line: It comes from Finnish director Juho Kuosmanen, whose 2016 film The Happiest Day in the Life of Olli Mäki was a lovely comedy about a real-life Finnish boxing champ in the 1960s.

Title: Compartment No 6 review – meet-uncute train romance is a Finnish Before Sunrise
Line: His new film is adapted from a novel of the same name by Finnish artist and author Rosa Liksom, and concerns a young Finnish student of archaeology, Laura (Seidi Haarla) who is in Moscow sometime in the early 90s; she has begun an impulsive affair with her professor, Irina (Dirana Drukarova).

Title: Compartment No 6 review – meet-uncute train romance is a Finnish Before Sunrise
Line: Under Irina’s tutelage, with her encouragement, and perhaps because this older woman does not care to have Laura hanging around much longer, Laura has resolved to make the tough rail journey up to Murmansk where she wants to view the petroglyphs there - mysterious rock drawings, thousands of years old.

Title: Compartment No 6 review – meet-uncute train romance is a Finnish Before Sunrise
Line: Sweet-natured, open-hearted Laura gets on this uncomfortable train in the freezing wintry cold, where she finds that she must share compartment number 6 with Vadim (Yuriy Borisov), a boorish, drunk young guy who is on his way to get a job in a coal mine in Murmansk and is openly abusive, misogynistic and philistine about Laura’s plans.

Title: Compartment No 6 review – meet-uncute train romance is a Finnish Before Sunrise
Line: And her phone calls back to Moscow reveal that Irina isn’t exactly pining for her.

Title: Compartment No 6 review – meet-uncute train romance is a Finnish Before Sunrise
Line: Of course, it isn’t too much of a stretch to see that after their meet-uncute, the relationship of Vadim and Laura is going to thaw.

Title: Compartment No 6 review – meet-uncute train romance is a Finnish Before Sunrise
Line: The romance that flowers between these two young people is in parallel with the romance of a long rail journey, and this is a very non-American equivalent of Richard Linklater’s Before Sunrise movies.

Title: Compartment No 6 review – meet-uncute train romance is a Finnish Before Sunrise
Line: Vadim’s scowling face and shaven, bullet head make him look a tough guy at first, but it isn’t long before we see him as a vulnerable little boy, never more so than when with Laura welcomes another Finnish guy to share their carriage - a self-admiringly sensitive type who insists on singing and playing his guitar.

Title: Compartment No 6 review – meet-uncute train romance is a Finnish Before Sunrise
Line: Vadim is fiercely sceptical and resentful of this preening interloper, and he is right to be.

Title: Compartment No 6 review – meet-uncute train romance is a Finnish Before Sunrise
Line: In the end, no one wants to help Laura find these petroglyphs that she has set her heart on and travelled so far to see, and it is Vadim himself who has to step up; there is charm and gentleness in this scene and the movie as a whole.

Title: Compartment No 6 review – meet-uncute train romance is a Finnish Before Sunrise
Line: • Compartment No 6 is released on 8 April in cinemas and on Curzon Home Cinema.
