Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: People on Australia’s east coast are finding strange uninvited guests lodged in their carpets and hopping around their homes after record rainfall.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: The small dull brown creatures are a type of prawn that live on land.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: They’re known as lawn prawns or forest hoppers, and they’re joining the growing list of critters searching for dry shelter in people’s homes in New South Wales and Queensland where frequent heavy rain has already caused several floods this year.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: “It’s not very often people see them and that’s why it’s quite surprising for people to find them in their homes,” said Shane Ahyong, a research scientist on marine invertebrates at the Australian Museum.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: “Usually they’re hidden, unless you’re looking for them you won’t find them.” Queensland resident Anne Carlin was baffled when she found hundreds in her home, posting a photo to Twitter of the “miniature prawn” and asking “Does anyone know what this is”.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: Another Queensland resident, Helen Bender, told the ABC she first noticed the tiny creatures dead in her home in December.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: She spent weeks trying to figure out what they were and whether they were a problem.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: The lawn prawns are harmless and are normally found by the thousands in moist soil beneath leaf litter on Australia’s east coast.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: But unlike their marine cousins, they can’t breathe underwater.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: So as the heavy rains swamp their habitat, they’re climbing into people’s homes.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: Once they are in people’s homes, they eventually die from lack of moisture, turning from brown to pink.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: While their marine counterparts are a popular dish, the lawn prawns do not compare on taste.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: “You can eat them if you want,” Ahyong said with a laugh.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: “But they won’t do much for you, they’re very small.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: “The key message is don’t see them as a threat, see them as a benefit.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: Please don’t use pesticides because that will kill them, having a lot of them in your leaf litter is the sign of a healthy system.” There are 30 native species of lawn prawns and these are some of what will be found in back yards.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: But there are also a number of introduced species that are thought to have been transported here in soil from Sri Lanka or India.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: “Besides the fact they’re just really cool, it’s good they’re being brought to people’s attention because we don’t often think of crustaceans in our back yard,” Ahyong said.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: “You think of insects, and you think of bees and birds and lizards.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: But crustaceans are actually playing a really important role in the ecosystem.” They act as a “recycler”, improving soil by eating decaying leaves and breaking down organic matter.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: “If you go into the back yard and dig around under mature leaf litter you’ll often see them.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: To escape predators they hop and bounce around.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: If you see things jumping around or shuffling quickly in the soil, it’s probably them.” Though it is yet unknown how the lawn prawn populations that live in state forests have been affected by floods, Ahyong said he doesn’t consider the populations of back yard lawn prawns found in homes at risk.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: But increased warming and flooding resulting from the climate crisis will inevitably have an impact on lawn prawns, he said.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: “Combine climate change with urbanisation and habitat loss, we are really reducing the number of potential sites that these animals can live in.” “Because they’re hiding in the soil we can destroy swathes of their environment without even knowing it, and that’s bad news for the animals that rely on them for what they do in the soil and rely on them for food.” Heavy rains have also affected the better known marine prawns.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: The floods have flushed farmed sea prawns out to sea, with one fisher catching an escaped prawn used as breeding stock in the commercial farms that weighed more than 20 times the average king prawn.

Title: Invasion of the lawn prawn: heavy rain drives tiny back yard crustaceans into Queensland homes
Line: While fishers are warning prawns will be scarce this season, John Morrongiello, a senior lecturer in marine biology at the University of Melbourne, said the nutrients being flushed into the sea from rivers are spawning fertile breeding grounds that will eventually be a boon for fisheries.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: In 1881, two young British princes serving as midshipmen in the Royal Navy visited Japan, where they had a meeting with the emperor.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: This encounter wasn’t the most significant between the royal families of Britain and Japan, or the most extravagant – the princes bought a metal teapot and cups as a gift for their father in a nascent tourist market – but it was emblematic of the long and complex interaction between the two countries.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: While in Japan, the princes, aged just 16 and 17, got tattoos on their arms: a couple of storks for Prince Albert and a dragon and a tiger for the future George V, Prince George.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: “Tattoos were part of naval culture and were a British aristocratic fashion in the late 19th century,” explains Rachel Peat, the curator of a new exhibition, Japan: Courts and Culture, which opened at the Queen’s Gallery this week.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: “But in Japan, tattooing had very different connotations.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: It has been both a revered art form and at various times illegal in Japanese history, so there is a mystique and almost danger to getting one, which might well have been part of the allure for the tourists.” The sense of something distant, desirable and difficult to access has been a key part of the western fascination for Japanese art, culture and objects.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: It is evidenced in this first exhibition dedicated to works of art from Japan in the royal collection, for which the Queen’s galleries have been specially redesigned.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: While it is not a comprehensive survey of Japanese art – no calligraphy or kimonos and only one netsuke miniature sculpture – it reveals an engrossing story of diplomacy, taste and power through artistry and craftsmanship.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: The first royal contact came in 1613, with an exchange of gifts that included a set of samurai armour, shortly before Japan closed itself to western influence for more than 200 years.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: Not that this put an end to the attraction for all things Japanese.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: If anything, the closure of Japan made its products all the more fashionable and sought after, and, via Chinese and Dutch merchants, the royal family continued to build its collection of porcelain and lacquer products, whose secrets of manufacture were still unknown in the west.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: The reopening of Japan in the 19th century prompted a renewal of royal visits and a new appreciation and understanding of Japanese art in the west, and the start of the 20th century saw warm relations between the countries.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: The rupture of the second world war was healed in the 1950s with a coronation gift from Emperor Hirohito to the new British queen and was widely regarded as an attempt to use art to symbolise a new era of cooperation.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: “These objects are normally dispersed across 15 different historic and royal residences,” says Peat.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: “So bringing them together and seeing them as a whole is quite something.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: Many of the objects are gifts directly commissioned by the imperial family, and in some cases even designed by them.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: The result is work of the most exquisite quality, but also work that reveals a fascinating history – complete with peaks and troughs – of an ever-changing relationship not only between courts, but between cultures.” From east to west: four artworks from the show Folding screen painting, 1860 This painting depicting Mount Fuji in the spring – one of a pair sent to Queen Victoria in 1860 – was thought to be lost, but was rediscovered during preparations for the exhibition.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: It is made of silk with hinges of paper and gold leaf, and is extremely fragile.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: The screens are considered to be paintings not furniture, and would be displayed flat to best show the work of the artists.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: It was among the first diplomatic gifts to be made after Japan reopened to the world following more than 200 years of isolation.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: Pair of pastille burners in the form of hares, 1680–1720 (main picture) These decorative porcelain figures represent the year of the rabbit and draw on wider eastern mythology about rabbits or hares being associated with the moon and notions of immortality.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: They also function as incense burners, with the smoke emerging through holes in the rockwork stumps on which the hares sit.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: Armour from the Myōchin school, 1537–1850 This samurai armour is constructed from leather, doeskin, horsehair, bear fur, gilt copper, gold filigree and thousands of tiny iron pieces laced together with vibrant blue and red silk to make a flexible covering that is wrapped round the body.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: It is likely that elements from several suits of armour were used to make this suit, which was presented to Queen Victoria’s son Alfred in 1869.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: He was the first overseas royal of any nationality to visit modern Japan.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: Cosmetic box and cover, c.1890–1905 This wooden box decorated with black, gold and silver lacquer was the first diplomatic gift after the second world war, given to the Queen by Hirohito, the Emperor Shōwa, to mark her coronation in 1953.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: It was made by Shirayama Shōsai who was one of the leading artists during a golden age of lacquer work in the early 20th century.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection
Line: Here he has depicted a heron, whose feathers are picked out in silver lacquer, accented with gold streaks.

Title: Art of diplomacy: 300 years of Japanese art in Britain’s royal collection

Title: ‘Toxic combination’ of issues threaten world’s health and human rights – BMA
Line: Health-related human rights are under intense threat across the globe with devastating consequences for the public and healthcare professionals, a new report from the British Medical Association warned.

Title: ‘Toxic combination’ of issues threaten world’s health and human rights – BMA
Line: The study, which examines the links between human rights and healthcare, identifies a “toxic combination” of emerging issues that have undermined human rights standards, putting renewed stress and pressure on populations around the world.

Title: ‘Toxic combination’ of issues threaten world’s health and human rights – BMA
Line: BMA researchers say climate change, disinformation, neoliberalism, populism and socioeconomic inequalities are threatening “the vulnerable, the foreign, the marginal, the displaced, the ‘other’.” “This is a really critical moment to think through whether we’re serious about equalities in healthcare and basic universal provision,” said Dr Julian Sheather, one of the authors of the report.

Title: ‘Toxic combination’ of issues threaten world’s health and human rights – BMA
Line: “We’ve got rising costs of healthcare, rising needs of healthcare and real challenges about how health goods can be distributed around the world.

Title: ‘Toxic combination’ of issues threaten world’s health and human rights – BMA
Line: Globally, we’re at a turning point.” Inequalities were brought into sharp focus by the pandemic with the more powerful, wealthy countries given greater access to vaccines and personal protective equipment, the BMA said.

Title: ‘Toxic combination’ of issues threaten world’s health and human rights – BMA
Line: Researchers found global cooperation had a direct impact on health outcomes, with resource-poor countries more exposed to Covid infections.

Title: ‘Toxic combination’ of issues threaten world’s health and human rights – BMA
Line: Social media and other new technologies allowed governments to deliver public health messaging around the pandemic, including monitoring and interventions such as test and trace, but it also gave rise to the spread of health misinformation and increased state surveillance encroaching on the privacy of its citizens.

Title: ‘Toxic combination’ of issues threaten world’s health and human rights – BMA
Line: This misinformation “undermines and undercuts” trust in the health authorities and medical opinion, Sheather said.

Title: ‘Toxic combination’ of issues threaten world’s health and human rights – BMA
Line: “Populist politicians of a particular ilk have shown themselves adept at channelling their [citizens’] fears for short-term political advantage.

Title: ‘Toxic combination’ of issues threaten world’s health and human rights – BMA
Line: The potential effects of these populist appeals on health-seeking behaviour can be extremely damaging,” Sheather said in the report, pointing to the example of Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro’s public discourse on Covid, who called the virus a “little flu”, which should be faced “like a man, not a boy”.

Title: ‘Toxic combination’ of issues threaten world’s health and human rights – BMA
Line: Conflict has also had an adverse effect on global human rights and health.

Title: ‘Toxic combination’ of issues threaten world’s health and human rights – BMA
Line: The protection of medical staff and facilities during conflict are of particular concern, with hospitals and medics targeted, as seen most recently in Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

Title: ‘Toxic combination’ of issues threaten world’s health and human rights – BMA
Line: “Medical professionals and facilities should be sacrosanct, yet we see them deliberately and systematically attacked,” Sheather said.

Title: ‘Toxic combination’ of issues threaten world’s health and human rights – BMA
Line: “We need to be moving to a time of restraint and respect for international humanitarian law.” Populations who have been displaced and sought asylum in neighbouring countries or farther afield are at greater risk of poor mental and physical health, and face significant challenges accessing healthcare.

Title: ‘Toxic combination’ of issues threaten world’s health and human rights – BMA
Line: The report sets out the effects forced displacement of the Roma population have had on living standards and healthcare.

Title: ‘Toxic combination’ of issues threaten world’s health and human rights – BMA
Line: It shows that one in three Roma are living in housing without running water and that Roma women are 4.5 times more likely to have a low birth-weight baby than a non-Roma woman, with their babies 2.8 times more likely to be born prematurely.

Title: ‘Toxic combination’ of issues threaten world’s health and human rights – BMA
Line: Research also highlights the plight of the 600,000 Myanmar Rohingyas trapped in the country, confined to camps with inadequate food, healthcare and education, and routinely subjected to state violence.

Title: ‘Toxic combination’ of issues threaten world’s health and human rights – BMA
Line: Those who have fled over the border to refugee camps in Bangladesh have limited access to healthcare, and inadequate resources to support the hundreds of thousands of people living there.

Title: ‘Toxic combination’ of issues threaten world’s health and human rights – BMA
Line: Climate change and its links to more prevalent diseases and virus strains, as well as the transfer of infections on migration routes, was also found to be a major contributing factor to human rights imbalances between countries.

Title: ‘Toxic combination’ of issues threaten world’s health and human rights – BMA
Line: Sheather says the transfer of viruses from non-human to human hosts, as seen during the pandemic, will “continue to be a feature of climate change”.

Title: ‘Toxic combination’ of issues threaten world’s health and human rights – BMA
Line: The BMA makes urgent recommendations to policymakers, including the removal of barriers for migrants to access healthcare systems and greater support from wealthier countries to displaced and migrant populations.

Title: ‘Toxic combination’ of issues threaten world’s health and human rights – BMA
Line: Clear recording of human rights violations during war, with a specific list of those that relate to health and healthcare were also urged, with health professionals calling for a strengthening of the international criminal court.

Title: Picasso portrait of lover and muse to appear at auction for first time
Line: A sensuous depiction of Pablo Picasso’s muse and lover as a multi-limbed sea creature, completed during the most prolific year of the artist’s life, is to appear at auction for the first time.

Title: Picasso portrait of lover and muse to appear at auction for first time
Line: Femme nue couchée (Naked woman reclining) is expected to sell for more than $60m next month, a reflection of the desirability among collectors of Picasso’s images of Marie-Thérèse Walter.

Title: Picasso portrait of lover and muse to appear at auction for first time
Line: “Picasso’s portraits of his golden muse Marie-Thérèse are undeniable hallmarks of 20th century art,” said Brooke Lampley, chair and head of global fine art sales at Sotheby’s, which is selling the painting.

Title: Picasso portrait of lover and muse to appear at auction for first time
Line: Femme nue couchée was “a deeply lyrical ode to the artist’s unbound desire for Marie-Thérèse; with her fin-like, endlessly pliable limbs, the portrait continues to enchant as it perfectly captures Picasso’s muse as the ultimate expression of his genius”.

Title: Picasso portrait of lover and muse to appear at auction for first time
Line: Picasso’s relationship with Walter – considered one of the great love affairs of the 20th century – was for many years a closely guarded secret.

Title: Picasso portrait of lover and muse to appear at auction for first time
Line: At the age of 45 and unhappily married, the artist fell for the 17-year-old Walter when he noticed her through the window of Galeries Lafayette in Paris in 1927.

Title: Picasso portrait of lover and muse to appear at auction for first time
Line: “I’m sure we shall do great things together.

Title: Picasso portrait of lover and muse to appear at auction for first time
Line: I’m Picasso,” he told the teenager, who had no idea who he was.

Title: Picasso portrait of lover and muse to appear at auction for first time
Line: She inspired paintings, drawings and sculptures, some of which are considered the greatest works from Picasso’s eight-decade-long career.

Title: Picasso portrait of lover and muse to appear at auction for first time
Line: An exhibition at Tate Modern four years ago was devoted to Picasso’s output in 1932, in particular his intense portraits of Walter.

Title: Picasso portrait of lover and muse to appear at auction for first time
Line: “There were many notable years in the long, dramatic career of Pablo Picasso, but 1932 stands out as particularly momentous,” said Julian Dawes, Sotheby’s co-head of modern art in New York.

Title: Picasso portrait of lover and muse to appear at auction for first time
Line: “In this ‘year of wonders’, Picasso produced the most sensuous depictions of his great muse and lover Marie-Thérèse Walter, who would inspire some of the artist’s most iconic images.” In Femme nue couchée, Walter is depicted with the sensuous limbs of a sea-creature.

Title: Picasso portrait of lover and muse to appear at auction for first time
Line: She was an enthusiastic and proficient swimmer, whose grace in the water was an enduring fascination for Picasso, who never learned to swim.

Title: Picasso portrait of lover and muse to appear at auction for first time
Line: The lovers had enjoyed trysts by the sea in the summer of 1928, when Picasso secretly installed Walter in a holiday camp close to where the artist, his then wife, Olga Khokhlova, a Russian-Ukrainian dancer, and their son Paulo were staying.

Title: Picasso portrait of lover and muse to appear at auction for first time
Line: Last year, Picasso’s Femme assise près d’une fenêtre (Marie-Thérèse) sold for $103.4m at auction in New York.

Title: England state school pupils as happy with life as private school peers – survey
Line: Young adults and teenagers who went to state schools in England are as happy with their lives as their peers at private schools, according to a new study by researchers at University College London.

Title: England state school pupils as happy with life as private school peers – survey
Line: Dr Morag Henderson, of UCL’s social research institute, the paper’s lead author, said: “Although school resource is greater in private schools, the academic stress students face might be too and so we see each force cancelling the other out.” The study – published in the Cambridge Journal of Education on Thursday – is based on responses from a national sample of more than 15,000 people born in 1989 to 1990 who attended school in England, and were surveyed as teenagers and later in their 20s.

Title: England state school pupils as happy with life as private school peers – survey
Line: “While these methods do not prove causality, the absence of significant positive effects implies that there is no evidence that parents who decided to pay for private schooling were gaining mental health and life satisfaction advantages for their children,” the authors stated.

Title: England state school pupils as happy with life as private school peers – survey
Line: The research measured participants’ mental health by asking questions such as: “Have you been able to concentrate on what you are doing?” and “Have you lost sleep over worry?” It found little difference in responses between the two groups before and after adjusting for factors such as social background and educational achievement.

Title: England state school pupils as happy with life as private school peers – survey
Line: Those who attended fee-paying independent schools did report higher levels of life satisfaction in their 20s.

Title: England state school pupils as happy with life as private school peers – survey
Line: But after responses were adjusted to exclude the effects of advantages such as higher income, house ownership and better exam results, the researchers again found no substantial differences in satisfaction levels.

Title: England state school pupils as happy with life as private school peers – survey

Title: England state school pupils as happy with life as private school peers – survey
Line: The study concluded that “there is no additional advantage of private schooling with respect to mental health and life satisfaction” for the cohort it studied.

Title: England state school pupils as happy with life as private school peers – survey
Line: But it cautioned that private schools have further increased their spending on wellbeing and pastoral support in the years since the sample group attended school.

Title: England state school pupils as happy with life as private school peers – survey

Title: England state school pupils as happy with life as private school peers – survey
Line: “This is speculation but it might be that we see state school students fare worse in terms of mental health compared to private school students, post-lockdown.

Title: Weatherwatch: the contrasts in Egypt’s desert climate
Line: Egypt, Africa’s most north-easterly country, is one of the hottest, driest and sunniest on Earth – its desert climate inhabitable only because of the Nile River, which brings water and allows irrigation for farming.

Title: Weatherwatch: the contrasts in Egypt’s desert climate
Line: However, Egypt’s size means there is a big contrast between the climates of the far north and far south.

Title: Weatherwatch: the contrasts in Egypt’s desert climate
Line: This is epitomised by the two cities at either end of the country: Alexandria, on the Mediterranean coast, and Aswan, at the head of Lake Nasser, towards Sudan.

Title: Weatherwatch: the contrasts in Egypt’s desert climate
Line: Alexandria has a typically pleasant Mediterranean climate, with hot, dry summers and warm winters, during which rain occasionally falls.

Title: Weatherwatch: the contrasts in Egypt’s desert climate
Line: Even so, the total annual rainfall for the city is only 235mm (less than 10 inc), which is still within the definition of “desert”.

Title: Weatherwatch: the contrasts in Egypt’s desert climate
Line: In summer, the hot wind known as the khamsin blows northwards from the country’s interior, often bringing dust and sand.

Title: Weatherwatch: the contrasts in Egypt’s desert climate
Line: Aswan, more than 620 miles (1,000km) to the south, gets a maximum of 10mm (less than half an inch) of rain a year; and sometimes none at all.

Title: Weatherwatch: the contrasts in Egypt’s desert climate
Line: Temperatures here are hot in winter, though at nights they fall into the low teens; and very hot – sometimes dangerously so – in summer, when mid-40C spells are not uncommon.

Title: Weatherwatch: the contrasts in Egypt’s desert climate
Line: The capital, Cairo, and the tourist sites at Luxor, are best visited from November to March, when the weather is usually dry, sunny and warm.

Title: By cancelling its LGBT conference, the government shows its lack of concern for our rights
Line: This week, the government cancelled its first global LGBTQ+ conference which was meant to further equality and help tackle pressing issues like violence and hate.

Title: By cancelling its LGBT conference, the government shows its lack of concern for our rights

Title: By cancelling its LGBT conference, the government shows its lack of concern for our rights

Title: By cancelling its LGBT conference, the government shows its lack of concern for our rights

Line: That must start with a commitment to legislating for a trans-inclusive ban on conversion practices.

Title: Country diary: A little egret does its best impression of a gull
Line: A shapeshifting bird has descended on our stretch of the River Ivel.

Title: Country diary: A little egret does its best impression of a gull
Line: It turns heads, commands attention, and fits the descriptions of both dainty and dumpy.

Title: Country diary: A little egret does its best impression of a gull
Line: My eyes lifted the other day from a pair of swans scudding across the mill pool towards the far side, where the river resumes its narrowed course.

Title: Country diary: A little egret does its best impression of a gull
Line: There was white beyond white, a little egret poking around the margins with such assurance and precision that it reminded me of a decisive shopper – one of those, one of those and, yes, I’ll take two of those.

Title: Country diary: A little egret does its best impression of a gull
Line: Over the winter, egrets were jittery, flighty visitors here, apt to lift off and swirl in agitation whenever I came into view.

Title: Country diary: A little egret does its best impression of a gull
Line: But this one, closer than any hitherto, once I had walked along the bank to confront it, was unfazed.

Title: Country diary: A little egret does its best impression of a gull
Line: Egrets do dainty.

Title: Country diary: A little egret does its best impression of a gull
Line: Moments earlier, its elfin figure, slight and slender, light on Marmite-dark pins, gave a twist of the head, a flick to the left, nod to the right.

Title: Country diary: A little egret does its best impression of a gull
Line: Poke, prod, jab.

Title: Country diary: A little egret does its best impression of a gull
Line: And then up it rose, flapped a little way, before settling as a no-neck dumpy heron.

Title: Country diary: A little egret does its best impression of a gull
Line: A row of birds perched on the river-spanning cage around a gas pipe: a sentry line of three black-headed gulls with chocolate heads, plus now the egret tagged on the end.

Title: Country diary: A little egret does its best impression of a gull
Line: I’d never seen any other bird share the gulls’ stance before, but they looked unbothered, maybe because the taller egret immediately shrank into itself so that it was just one of the gulls.

Title: Country diary: A little egret does its best impression of a gull
Line: Members of the heron family have a tendency towards habitual behaviour, and it wasn’t a complete surprise to find the egret on the same perch 24 hours later.

Title: Country diary: A little egret does its best impression of a gull
Line: The gulls were gone.

Title: Country diary: A little egret does its best impression of a gull
Line: The bird, exposed and hunched, eyed a man and a dog who were walking the bank towards it.

Title: Country diary: A little egret does its best impression of a gull
Line: The egret turned its head by degrees to see them off.

Title: Country diary: A little egret does its best impression of a gull
Line: Just then a light breeze arose, ruffling the compact shape, lifting a nuptial plume briefly from its nape as if it were a curl out of place.

Title: Country diary: A little egret does its best impression of a gull
Line: Was this one of a breeding pair, perhaps?

Title: Country diary: A little egret does its best impression of a gull
Line: • Country Diary is on Twitter at @gdncountrydiary

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: If the rest of the world followed Australia’s “leadership” on cutting greenhouse gas emissions and reaching net zero, what would that mean?

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: This was the question we were left to ponder after the assistant energy minister, Tim Wilson, defended the Morrison government’s record this week after the latest UN climate assessment was released.

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: “We need global emissions to come down, which means we need other countries to follow our leadership in making sure they take decisions and back them in,” Wilson told the ABC, while criticising the UK and China for “backsliding” and a lack of commitment on targets.

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: Despite having multiple opportunities in recent years to increase its 2030 emissions reduction target – including before the most recent UN climate talks in Glasgow – Australia has stuck like glue to its unambitious Abbott-era goal, agreed almost seven years ago.

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: That was not so much a backslide as self-induced whiplash.

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: Does this “leadership” include celebrating booming coal and gas exports, as the resources minister Keith Pitt did last month?

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: Does it include a “gas-fired recovery”?

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: Does it include being the world’s second-largest exporter of thermal coal and the joint biggest exporter of LNG?

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: Does it include approving four coalmines in a month, just weeks before the Glasgow talks?

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: Is asking for coal plants to run for their entire lifetime, as the prime minister has done, something that all other countries should be doing?

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning Wilson also claimed the Morrison government was the first “in Australian history to announce a comprehensive economy-wide plan towards carbon neutrality by 2050.” This “economy-wide plan” equates to choosing several technologies for funding and development and then setting some “stretch goals”.

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: And here is your almost weekly reminder that the government’s modelling of its plan showed that by 2050, Australia would be short of zero by 226m tonnes of CO2-equivalent.

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: The “plan” said that under these technology goals, Australia would still need to buy 94m tonnes of overseas offsets and generate 38m tonnes from a controversial negative emissions technology which experts have described as farcical and unproven.

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: Gas to go?

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: Australia’s powerful gas lobby said the IPCC’s report “confirms the important role natural gas and its decarbonisation tools play” to cut emissions.

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: The Australian Petroleum Production & Exploration Association chief executive, Andrew McConville, said: “Gas will continue to be a part of the future cleaner energy mix as a cleaner alternative that complements so many of the pathways to net zero by 2050.” What the IPCC report actually said is far more nuanced and conditional, making clear that getting to net zero under its various scenarios would see the use of gas fall.

Line: The IPCC report also says investments in fossil fuel infrastructure will see energy systems “locked-in” to higher emissions, “making it harder to limit warming to 2C or 1.5C.” Budget for higher electricity prices?

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: Last week’s official budget papers claimed the government “has achieved its goal of wholesale electricity prices under $70/MWh” in the past two financial years.

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?

Line: They are still rising, he says, and will probably be passed on to consumers by retailers soon.

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: McConnell said the reason behind these price increases was partly down to the rising cost of coal and gas as countries exclude sources from Russia (which, as I mentioned earlier, was an issue celebrated last month by resources minister Keith Pitt).

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: Bjorn again Commentator and political scientist Bjorn Lomborg appeared annoyed that UN secretary general, António Guterres, and other world leaders are still making the climate crisis a priority as Russian forces kill civilians in Ukraine.

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: In a column in The Australian, which also ran in the Wall St Journal, Lomborg wrote “the global elite has an unhealthy obsession with climate change.” Under a threat of nuclear war, Lomborg pointed to the supposed costs of getting to net zero, referencing a report from consultants McKinsey.

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: The report, Lomborg claimed, showed “the policies will cost $US9.2tn every year until net zero is supposed to be achieved in 2050” and that “according to the McKinsey study” this meant achieving net zero would “cost every American family $US19,300 a year.” Yet Lomborg did not explain that the same McKinsey report said this spending “should not be seen as merely costs” and that “many of the investments have positive return profiles”.

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: A spokesperson for McKinsey & Company told Temperature Check the $9.2tn figure related to total spend and not an increase, and included $2.7tn that would continue to be spent “on high-emissions assets”.

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: “Furthermore, our projection shows that if the current policies put in place across countries, as well as their expected population and income growth, were accounted for, the increase could be only about $1tn annually,” the spokesperson said.

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: That spending, McKinsey said, “would prevent the further buildup of physical risks and the additional costs arising from a more disorderly transition, which could be sizeable in both economic and humanitarian terms.” And what of Lomborg’s claim that McKinsey had found achieving net zero would cost every American family US$19,300 each year?

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: This was “a mischaracterisation of our work”, a spokesperson said, adding “such a claim overstates and oversimplifies the manner in which costs of the transition would be shouldered.” Private enterprise would carry out a “significant portion” of the spending, McKinsey said, and some of this “eventually flows to households in the form of supplier payments, salaries and consumer surplus”.

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: “This is not a public sector expense that would be financed solely by taxpayer’s money,” McKinsey said.

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: Lomborg told Temperature Check his description of the $9.2tn figure as a cost was “similar to how Bloomberg describes the report with its headline “McKinsey Pegs the Price Tag of a Livable Climate at $9.2 Trillion a Year”.

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: He said: “We get both energy, jobs, and zero CO₂ emissions for this cost, but this is what is normally understood to come along with the cost of a policy.” Lomborg also argued McKinsey’s reference to the additional cost being as low as $1tn a year was across two scenarios that were not comparable because they assumed different energy outputs.

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: McKinsey rejected this claim, saying “the relevant metric is not total energy output, but rather the ability to meet the world’s energy needs.” McKinsey added it was “incomplete to consider those [$9.2tn] costs in a vacuum without mention of the anticipated benefits of the policies”.

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: “For this reason, we urge consideration of the benefits alongside the costs so a more informed decision on the value of the investment can be made.” Lomborg claimed it was “absolutely relevant” to “highlight the cost per family” because he claimed the spending “can only be shouldered by Americans”.

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: McKinsey said framing the spending as a cost to individual families “misstates the distribution of costs and unfairly leaves out the value of the benefits” to families.

Title: What would following Australia’s ‘leadership’ on the climate crisis actually look like?
Line: A statement added: “While you could potentially argue that a certain figure would be spent in the United States per person or per family on average, it is simply untrue that every American family would be shouldering that bill or that they would be shouldering it at the same rate and in the same fashion.”

Title: Scott Morrison caves in to co-funding Queensland flood resilience package after fierce criticism
Line: The prime minister, Scott Morrison, says the commonwealth will co-fund a $741m natural disaster resilience package for flood-prone Queensland communities – just a day after rejecting the request and claiming it was not his government’s responsibility.

Title: Scott Morrison caves in to co-funding Queensland flood resilience package after fierce criticism
Line: Morrison made the about-face during an interview with Brisbane radio station 4BC on Thursday morning.

Title: Scott Morrison caves in to co-funding Queensland flood resilience package after fierce criticism
Line: It followed fierce criticism of the Morrison government on Wednesday, including from the Insurance Council of Australia, which said the federal government could not “wash its hands” of responsibility.

Title: Scott Morrison caves in to co-funding Queensland flood resilience package after fierce criticism
Line: The Queensland premier, Annastacia Palaszczuk, wrote to Morrison on 19 March asking to go halves in the package, designed to pay for retrofitting, house raising or the voluntary buyback of flood-damaged homes.

Title: Scott Morrison caves in to co-funding Queensland flood resilience package after fierce criticism
Line: Morrison wrote to Palaszczuk on Tuesday night rejecting the request.

Title: Scott Morrison caves in to co-funding Queensland flood resilience package after fierce criticism
Line: He said in his letter that the measures were “outside the scope” of federal disaster recovery programs and the responsibility of state and local governments.

Title: Scott Morrison caves in to co-funding Queensland flood resilience package after fierce criticism
Line: When asked about the situation on Thursday morning, Morrison said the federal government had already committed more money to flood recovery than the Queensland government and that the requests made “go well beyond” others for “floods of this nature”.

Title: Scott Morrison caves in to co-funding Queensland flood resilience package after fierce criticism
Line: He said the federal government would now pay for half the resilience package.

Title: Scott Morrison caves in to co-funding Queensland flood resilience package after fierce criticism
Line: “If Queensland wants to play politics with floods before an election, that’s up to them,” Morrison said.

Title: Scott Morrison caves in to co-funding Queensland flood resilience package after fierce criticism
Line: “I don’t want to play politics with this, I just want to make sure people get the help they need.

Title: Scott Morrison caves in to co-funding Queensland flood resilience package after fierce criticism
Line: “Yes, we will provide that support.

Title: Scott Morrison caves in to co-funding Queensland flood resilience package after fierce criticism
Line: Yes, it is beyond the scope of what is normally done.” At a press conference in the flood-hit suburb of Goodna, Queensland’s treasurer and acting premier, Cameron Dick, said it was “regrettable that it took so long for the prime minister to act”.

Title: Scott Morrison caves in to co-funding Queensland flood resilience package after fierce criticism
Line: “It took him three weeks to consider our proposal.

Title: Scott Morrison caves in to co-funding Queensland flood resilience package after fierce criticism
Line: In 36 hours, after the prime minister said no, he’s now said yes,” Dick said.

Title: Scott Morrison caves in to co-funding Queensland flood resilience package after fierce criticism
Line: “This should not be the matter of whether there’s an election or not, this should be a matter of government business.” Dick labelled as “nonsense” a claim from the prime minister that more transparency was needed to ensure payments were being made.

Title: Scott Morrison caves in to co-funding Queensland flood resilience package after fierce criticism
Line: “The Queensland Reconstruction Authority is responsible … for all resilience payments,” Dick said.

Title: Scott Morrison caves in to co-funding Queensland flood resilience package after fierce criticism
Line: “Currently, [the prime minister has] two advisers on the board ...

Line: he knows exactly what we do with the money.” Morrison told 4BC the federal government would attach “conditions” to the payment that demanded Queensland be “transparent with the payments being made … I want them to report to the public”.

Title: Scott Morrison caves in to co-funding Queensland flood resilience package after fierce criticism
Line: He claimed the Queensland government was sitting on $52m provided for previous disaster recovery, a claim Guardian Australia is seeking to verify.

Title: Scott Morrison caves in to co-funding Queensland flood resilience package after fierce criticism
Line: On Wednesday, the Insurance Council of Australia released a statement that criticised the federal government’s decision not to help fund the resilience package.

Title: Scott Morrison caves in to co-funding Queensland flood resilience package after fierce criticism
Line: In February, the ICA released a report calling for $726m to be invested jointly by the Queensland and federal governments over five years.

Line: It had welcomed the resilience funding when it was announced by the Queensland government.

Title: Scott Morrison caves in to co-funding Queensland flood resilience package after fierce criticism
Line: “As severe rain and flooding continues to impact the east coast, the failure of the federal government to match Queensland’s investment in measures to improve household and community protections against extreme weather is disappointing and short-sighted,” the ICA’s chief executive, Andrew Hall, said.

Title: Scott Morrison caves in to co-funding Queensland flood resilience package after fierce criticism
Line: “If Australia is to get serious about improving our resilience to flood, bushfire and cyclone, all levels of government must contribute.

Title: UK’s top 0.1% earners have annual income of over half a million, says IFS
Line: The top 0.1% of earners in the UK have annual incomes in excess of £500,000, according to a study by a leading thinktank that shows the effect of “unfair” tax rates available to business owners.

Title: UK’s top 0.1% earners have annual income of over half a million, says IFS
Line: More than 50,000 people in the top income bracket account for 6% of all earnings – 60 times greater than their population share, said the Institute for Fiscal Studies in a report covering the 10 years to 2019.

Title: UK’s top 0.1% earners have annual income of over half a million, says IFS
Line: It showed that more than half of the top 1% richest adults lived in London and the south-east, while almost 60% were aged between 45-64, and as few as a fifth were women.

Title: UK’s top 0.1% earners have annual income of over half a million, says IFS
Line: The report, Top Income Inequality and Tax Policy, shows that earnings from self-employment and business ownership were far more important for those at the top end compared with low and middle earners.

Title: UK’s top 0.1% earners have annual income of over half a million, says IFS
Line: Suggesting that this has consequences for inequality because income from company ownership is taxed at a lower rate than earnings from work, the report argues that reforms could be launched to tackle unfairness in the tax system.

Title: UK’s top 0.1% earners have annual income of over half a million, says IFS
Line: Alex Beer, welfare programme head at the Nuffield Foundation, which funded the research as part of the IFS Deaton review of inequalities, said: “The current design of the tax system, including the way in which different forms of income are taxed at different rates, is unfair and inefficient, penalising employees and distorting investment decisions, to the detriment of social wellbeing.” According to the report, business income – from either self-employment or owning and running a company – accounts for 21% of total incomes for the top 1% of adults and 29% for the top 0.1%, compared with just 9% for the rest of the population at large.

Title: UK’s top 0.1% earners have annual income of over half a million, says IFS
Line: It said business owner-managers could effectively choose to take income out of their company through the form of a salary, dividends, or capital gains – allowing them to benefit from lower rates of tax.

Title: UK’s top 0.1% earners have annual income of over half a million, says IFS
Line: The report pointed to a preferential 10% rate of capital gains tax, called business asset disposal relief, while saying that company owner-managers were able to access tax rates of just 27% on income taken in the form of capital gains.

Title: UK’s top 0.1% earners have annual income of over half a million, says IFS
Line: In comparison, the average tax rate on wage earners in the top 1% is 42%.

Title: UK’s top 0.1% earners have annual income of over half a million, says IFS
Line: The government sets the basic rate of income tax at 20% on earnings above the tax-free personal allowance of £12,571, up to £50,270, with a rate of 40% on income above £50,271, and 45% above £150,000.

Title: UK’s top 0.1% earners have annual income of over half a million, says IFS
Line: Despite the lower rates open to business owners, the IFS said taxes on the highest-paid wage earners had increased since 2010.

Title: UK’s top 0.1% earners have annual income of over half a million, says IFS
Line: As a result, the share of overall after-tax income in the UK received by the highest earners had fallen from 14% in 2009-10 to 11% in 2018-19.

Title: UK’s top 0.1% earners have annual income of over half a million, says IFS
Line: Illustrating the gulf between public and private sector pay at senior levels, the Taxpayers’ Alliance said in a report earlier this week that only 2,921 people employed by local authorities in 2020-21 received more than £100,000 in total remuneration and 739 received over £150,000, 46 more than the previous year.

Title: UK’s top 0.1% earners have annual income of over half a million, says IFS
Line: According to the Institute for Government, just 1,560 of the 456,410 civil servants earned more than £100,000 in 2020.

Title: UK’s top 0.1% earners have annual income of over half a million, says IFS
Line: Across the whole civil service, the majority of staff (55%) were paid below £30,000.

Title: Inflo, Ed Sheeran and Adele lead Ivor Novello nominations
Line: Adele, Ed Sheeran and Inflo, a musician billed as “the most influential and mysterious producer on the planet”, have dominated the Ivor Novello award nominations in a year in which drill artists were also recognised by the most prestigious songwriting awards in the UK.

Title: Inflo, Ed Sheeran and Adele lead Ivor Novello nominations
Line: Dean Wynton Josiah Cover, AKA Inflo, leads the award nominations, which celebrate Britain’s best songwriters and composers, with four, while Ed Sheeran – who has just won a plagiarism battle over his song Shape of You – has three nods and Adele is in the running for two awards, including songwriter of the year.

Title: Inflo, Ed Sheeran and Adele lead Ivor Novello nominations
Line: Adele will compete for the songwriting award with Coldplay, Raye, Dave and Ed Sheeran, who also has two songs – Bad Habits and Shivers – nominated in the PRS for music most performed work category.

Title: Inflo, Ed Sheeran and Adele lead Ivor Novello nominations
Line: Inflo has credits on three of the five albums nominated in the best album category, with work on Cleo Sol’s Mother, Sault’s Nine and Little Simz’s Sometimes I Might Be Introvert, while Nottingham duo Sleaford Mods’ LP Spare Ribs and Laura Mvula’s 80s pop-inflected Pink Noise round out the category.

Title: Inflo, Ed Sheeran and Adele lead Ivor Novello nominations
Line: Mvula said she was delighted to receive the nomination for the album she worked on during lockdown after being dropped by her label, despite producing two Mercury prize-nominated albums.

Title: Inflo, Ed Sheeran and Adele lead Ivor Novello nominations
Line: “Sometimes it was hard to imagine getting to the finish line, so to know that it has made some impact in such strange times is really exciting for me,” she added.

Title: Inflo, Ed Sheeran and Adele lead Ivor Novello nominations
Line: The songwriter said the lineup for this year’s Novellos, which is one of the most diverse ever, was important, especially for young Britons who will see people like themselves represented.

Title: Inflo, Ed Sheeran and Adele lead Ivor Novello nominations
Line: She said: “They need to know that they can do whatever they want to do, especially when it comes to creativity and the arts.

Title: Inflo, Ed Sheeran and Adele lead Ivor Novello nominations
Line: I’m genuinely thrilled to feel empowered and celebrated, and to be a symbol of something that is needed and positive in this ever-changing climate.” The hip-hop genre drill was also recognised with Russ Millions and Tion Wayne’s number-one single Body nominated in the best contemporary song category, alongside FKA Twigs’ Don’t Judge Me, a collaboration with rapper Headie One and Fred Again.

Title: Inflo, Ed Sheeran and Adele lead Ivor Novello nominations
Line: James Blake’s track Coming Back, featuring SZA, PinkPantheress’s Just For Me and Little Simz’s I Love You, I Hate You all secured nods.

Title: Inflo, Ed Sheeran and Adele lead Ivor Novello nominations
Line: Elsewhere, Jonny Greenwood’s soundtrack for Pablo Larraín’s Diana, Princess of Wales biopic, Spencer, is up against scores for After Love, Censor, The World To Come and Edgar Wright’s time-travelling psychological thriller Last Night In Soho.

Title: Inflo, Ed Sheeran and Adele lead Ivor Novello nominations
Line: Inflo’s domination of the Ivor Novello nominations continues his meteoric rise.

Title: Inflo, Ed Sheeran and Adele lead Ivor Novello nominations
Line: He has already won a Novello for Little Simz’s Grey Area and worked on Michael Kiwanuka’s Mercury-prize-winning album Kiwanuka, before teaming up with Simz again on her award-winning album Sometimes I Might Be Introvert and contributing to Adele’s 30.

Title: Inflo, Ed Sheeran and Adele lead Ivor Novello nominations
Line: He is a member of the press-shy Sault project, which has melded hip-hop, soul, spoken word and R&B over the course of five releases, and at this year’s Brits he became the first black Briton to win producer of the year, following in the footsteps of Brian Eno, Peter Gabriel and Calvin Harris.

Title: UK’s freedom of information laws are being undermined, warn journalists
Line: More than 100 journalists, politicians and campaigners have signed an open letter warning that the UK’s freedom of information (FoI) laws are being undermined by a lack of resources and government departments obstructing lawful requests.

Title: UK’s freedom of information laws are being undermined, warn journalists
Line: The signatories include the editor-in-chief of the Guardian, Katharine Viner, the editor of the Observer, Paul Webster, as well as the shadow solicitor general, Andy Slaughter, the former Brexit secretary David Davis, and the former Green party leader Caroline Lucas.

Title: UK’s freedom of information laws are being undermined, warn journalists
Line: The letter, which was coordinated by the online news organisation openDemocracy, is addressed to the new information commissioner, John Edwards, who is responsible for enforcing FoI law, which grants members of the public the legal right to request official information from public bodies.

Title: UK’s freedom of information laws are being undermined, warn journalists
Line: Edwards’ organisation, the Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO), reviews complaints against public bodies that have refused FoI requests and can order them to release material if they have failed to comply with the law.

Title: UK’s freedom of information laws are being undermined, warn journalists
Line: However, there is growing concern among journalists and researchers that the UK’s FoI system is increasingly being frustrated by under-resourcing and deliberate non-compliance by government departments.

Title: UK’s freedom of information laws are being undermined, warn journalists
Line: The Campaign for Freedom of Information recently reported that backlogs at the ICO had become so extensive that it was taking an entire year for case officers to be assigned to review complaints.

Title: UK’s freedom of information laws are being undermined, warn journalists
Line: Last year a judge accused the Cabinet Office of having “misled” a tribunal about the operation of an alleged blacklisting system for FoI requests from journalists, called Clearing House, and described a “profound lack of transparency” surrounding the unit.

Title: UK’s freedom of information laws are being undermined, warn journalists
Line: The open letter calls for the ICO to assign more resources to FoI casework, monitoring of public bodies that fail to comply with the law, and stronger enforcement protocols for government bodies that repeatedly flout the law.

Title: UK’s freedom of information laws are being undermined, warn journalists
Line: It also recommends the extension of FoI to cover private companies that provide public services.

Title: UK’s freedom of information laws are being undermined, warn journalists
Line: “As the British public is still being kept in the dark over Partygate, the importance of transparency has rarely been more obvious,” said Peter Geoghegan, the editor-in-chief of openDemocracy.

Title: UK’s freedom of information laws are being undermined, warn journalists
Line: “FoI is a key tool for holding public bodies to account, but currently the Information Commissioner’s Office is not ensuring that the Freedom of Information Act delivers.

Title: UK’s freedom of information laws are being undermined, warn journalists
Line: We welcome the new information commissioner’s listening exercise and are keen to share our views on how FoI can be better policed.” Viner said: “Journalism in the public interest often depends on freedom of information laws, which help the public understand the decisions made by the authorities.

Title: UK’s freedom of information laws are being undermined, warn journalists
Line: Such laws are essential to a well-functioning democracy.

Title: UK’s freedom of information laws are being undermined, warn journalists
Line: “When the government fails to meet its transparency commitments, it is essential that the ICO is able to step in to make sure ministers and public bodies comply with the law.” In response to the letter, Information Commissioner John Edwards said: “We acknowledge the concerns expressed in this letter.

Title: UK’s freedom of information laws are being undermined, warn journalists
Line: FOI plays an important part in civic engagement and holding public services to account, and we share the desire to see the law work effectively.” He continued: “We all benefit from a modern law, and I think there are suggestions in this letter that warrant further consideration.” Simon Mundell, a Cabinet Office spokesperson, said: “This government remains fully committed to its transparency agenda, routinely disclosing information beyond its obligations under the FOI Act, and releasing more proactive publications than ever before.” He added that the Clearing House had existed since 2004, and was intended to ensure “a consistent approach to dealing with FOIs across government” and that “requests for particularly sensitive information are handled appropriately”.

Title: Liberty threatens to sue government over ‘racist’ joint enterprise law
Line: The human rights group Liberty is threatening to sue the government and Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) over the bitterly contested law of joint enterprise, arguing that it is discredited and racist in the way the authorities pursue it.

Title: Liberty threatens to sue government over ‘racist’ joint enterprise law
Line: Under the law, people present when a person is killed can be convicted of murder despite not committing any serious violence themselves, if they are found to have “encouraged or assisted” the perpetrator.

Title: Liberty threatens to sue government over ‘racist’ joint enterprise law
Line: Liberty is acting for the campaign group Joint Enterprise Not Guilty By Association (Jengba), which supports approximately 1,400 people in prison who believe they have been unjustly convicted of serious crimes perpetrated by somebody else.

Title: Liberty threatens to sue government over ‘racist’ joint enterprise law
Line: Many joint enterprise prosecutions cast all participants in an incident as a gang, which ascribes to them a collective motive for an attack.

Title: Liberty threatens to sue government over ‘racist’ joint enterprise law
Line: There have long been accusations, supported by academic studies and parliamentary inquiries, that the gang label is attached disproportionately and without adequate evidence to black and minority-ethnic young men.

Title: Liberty threatens to sue government over ‘racist’ joint enterprise law
Line: The Guardian has reported extensively on the 2017 case in which seven black and mixed-race teenagers were convicted of murder, and four more of manslaughter, after the fatal stabbing in Moss Side, Manchester, of Abdul Hafidah, 18, by one of them.

Title: Liberty threatens to sue government over ‘racist’ joint enterprise law
Line: Greater Manchester police and the CPS portrayed all the young men as a gang who “controlled territory” but presented minimal evidence of criminal gang activity, and most of the defendants had no criminal records.

Title: Liberty threatens to sue government over ‘racist’ joint enterprise law
Line: Neither the Ministry of Justice (MoJ) nor the CPS records numbers of joint enterprise prosecutions, nor the defendants’ ethnicity or age, nor whether gang evidence was advanced in a case.

Title: Liberty threatens to sue government over ‘racist’ joint enterprise law
Line: Liberty argues that means the authorities are breaching their duties under the Equality Act because they are failing to “ascertain the extent of, and eliminate, any race discrimination in the use of joint enterprise laws”.

Title: Liberty threatens to sue government over ‘racist’ joint enterprise law
Line: In a letter sent to justice secretary Dominic Raab and director of public prosecutions Max Hill last month, Liberty called on the MoJ and the CPS to immediately begin recording and publishing such data, and “properly take into account” the duty to apply the joint enterprise law equally.

Title: Liberty threatens to sue government over ‘racist’ joint enterprise law
Line: Liberty threatened to issue a judicial review claim against both the MoJ and the CPS if they did not respond positively by Monday, 4 April.

Title: Liberty threatens to sue government over ‘racist’ joint enterprise law
Line: Both have asked for more time to respond.

Title: Liberty threatens to sue government over ‘racist’ joint enterprise law
Line: Lana Adamou, a lawyer at Liberty, said: “We all want our communities to be safe, and for our laws to treat us equally.

Title: Liberty threatens to sue government over ‘racist’ joint enterprise law
Line: But joint enterprise is overwhelmingly used against people from marginalised communities, especially young black men, and drags people unfairly into the criminal justice system.

Title: Liberty threatens to sue government over ‘racist’ joint enterprise law
Line: “It’s completely unacceptable that there is still no official data being recorded about how the doctrine is used and who it is used against.

Title: Liberty threatens to sue government over ‘racist’ joint enterprise law
Line: By failing to do so, the justice system has been recklessly sweeping thousands of young black men into the prison system.” Gloria Morrison, co-founder of Jengba, said that joint enterprise has been applied in a racist way to “over-criminalise” people, and described it as “common law, used against common people, that makes no common sense”.

Title: Liberty threatens to sue government over ‘racist’ joint enterprise law
Line: A CPS spokesperson said: “We have received a letter from Liberty regarding joint enterprise prosecutions and we will respond in due course.” An MoJ spokesperson said: “While charging decisions are made by independent prosecutors, we are currently considering the feasibility of collecting data on joint enterprise cases.”
